I tried to drink it away
I tried to put one in the air
I tried to dance it away
I tried to change it with my hair

I ran my credit card bill up
Thought a new dress would make it better
I tried to work it away
But that just made me even sadder

I tried to keep myself busy
I ran around in circles
Think I made myself dizzy
I slept it away, I sexed it away
I read it away
Away

Away, away, away, away, away
Away, away, away, away, away

Well, it's like cranes in the sky
Sometimes, I don't wanna feel those metal clouds
Yeah, it's like cranes in the sky
Sometimes, I don't wanna feel those metal clouds

[Verse 4]
I tried to run it away
Thought then my head'd be feeling clearer
I traveled seventy states
Thought moving 'round'd make me feel better

[Verse 5]
I tried to let go my lover
Thought if I was alone then maybe I could recover
To write it away or cry it away (Don't you cry, baby)
Away

But it's like cranes in the sky
Sometimes, I don't wanna feel those metal clouds

Sometimes, I don't wanna feel those metal—

description.plain:
“Cranes in the Sky” describes Solange’s attempts at avoiding painful feelings

While asked by her sister Beyonce about the meaning of the song in Interview magazine, she explained:

“Cranes in the Sky” is actually a song that I wrote eight years ago. It’s the only song on the album that I wrote independently of the record, and it was a really rough time. I know you remember that time. I was just coming out of my relationship with Julez’s father. We were junior high school sweethearts, and so much of your identity in junior high is built on who you’re with. You see the world through the lens of how you identify and have been identified at that time. So I really had to take a look at myself, outside of being a mother and a wife, and internalize all of these emotions that I had been feeling through that transition. I was working through a lot of challenges at every angle of my life, and a lot of self-doubt, a lot of pity-partying. And I think every woman in her twenties has been there—where it feels like no matter what you are doing to fight through the thing that is holding you back, nothing can fill that void. I used to write and record a lot in Miami during that time, when there was a real estate boom in America, and developers were developing all of this new property. There was a new condo going up every ten feet. You recorded a lot there as well, and I think we experienced Miami as a place of refuge and peace. We weren’t out there wilin’ out and partying. I remember looking up and seeing all of these cranes in the sky. They were so heavy and such an eyesore, and not what I identified with peace and refuge. I remember thinking of it as an analogy for my transition—this idea of building up, up, up that was going on in our country at the time, all of this excessive building, and not really dealing with what was in front of us. And we all know how that ended. That crashed and burned. It was a catastrophe. And that line came to me because it felt so indicative of what was going on in my life as well. And, eight years later, it’s really interesting that now, here we are again, not seeing what’s happening in our country, not wanting to put into perspective all of these ugly things that are staring us in the face.

Solange also shared how the song was made on her Instagram:

Timing. I wrote “Cranes in The Sky” 8 years ago. It was 8 years ago @raphael_saadiq handed me a cd with a few instrumentals. One was just drums, strings, and bass. I went home and wrote “Cranes” that night in my hotel room.
When I finished writing and creating #aseatatthetable in a little house in New Iberia, Louisiana…..I revisited “Cranes” once again. I called Raphael that night and asked if he would help me to elevate the production on a few of the other songs of the album to see their fullest potential. I am so happy 8 years later Cranes is finally out in the world.

In February 2017, Solange won her first Grammy for “Best R&B Performance” with this very song.

“Cranes in the Sky” describes Solange’s attempts at avoiding painful feelings

While asked by her sister Beyonce about the meaning of the song in Interview magazine, she explained:

“Cranes in the Sky” is actually a song that I wrote eight years ago. It’s the only song on the album that I wrote independently of the record, and it was a really rough time. I know you remember that time. I was just coming out of my relationship with Julez’s father. We were junior high school sweethearts, and so much of your identity in junior high is built on who you’re with. You see the world through the lens of how you identify and have been identified at that time. So I really had to take a look at myself, outside of being a mother and a wife, and internalize all of these emotions that I had been feeling through that transition. I was working through a lot of challenges at every angle of my life, and a lot of self-doubt, a lot of pity-partying. And I think every woman in her twenties has been there—where it feels like no matter what you are doing to fight through the thing that is holding you back, nothing can fill that void. I used to write and record a lot in Miami during that time, when there was a real estate boom in America, and developers were developing all of this new property. There was a new condo going up every ten feet. You recorded a lot there as well, and I think we experienced Miami as a place of refuge and peace. We weren’t out there wilin’ out and partying. I remember looking up and seeing all of these cranes in the sky. They were so heavy and such an eyesore, and not what I identified with peace and refuge. I remember thinking of it as an analogy for my transition—this idea of building up, up, up that was going on in our country at the time, all of this excessive building, and not really dealing with what was in front of us. And we all know how that ended. That crashed and burned. It was a catastrophe. And that line came to me because it felt so indicative of what was going on in my life as well. And, eight years later, it’s really interesting that now, here we are again, not seeing what’s happening in our country, not wanting to put into perspective all of these ugly things that are staring us in the face.

Timing. I wrote “Cranes in The Sky” 8 years ago. It was 8 years ago @raphael_saadiq handed me a cd with a few instrumentals. One was just drums, strings, and bass. I went home and wrote “Cranes” that night in my hotel room.

annotations: [Chorus]

In an Interview Q&A with Beyoncé, Solange explained the song and hook:

Cranes in the Sky' is actually a song that I wrote eight years ago. It’s the only song on the album that I wrote independently of the record, and it was a really rough time. I know you remember that time. I was just coming out of my relationship with Julez’s father. We were junior high school sweethearts, and so much of your identity in junior high is built on who you’re with. You see the world through the lens of how you identify and have been identified at that time. So I really had to take a look at myself, outside of being a mother and a wife, and internalize all of these emotions that I had been feeling through that transition. I was working through a lot of challenges at every angle of my life, and a lot of self-doubt, a lot of pity-partying. And I think every woman in her twenties has been there—where it feels like no matter what you are doing to fight through the thing that is holding you back, nothing can fill that void. I used to write and record a lot in Miami during that time, when there was a real estate boom in America, and developers were developing all of this new property. There was a new condo going up every ten feet. You recorded a lot there as well, and I think we experienced Miami as a place of refuge and peace. We weren’t out there wilin' out and partying. I remember looking up and seeing all of these cranes in the sky. They were so heavy and such an eyesore, and not what I identified with peace and refuge. I remember thinking of it as an analogy for my transition—this idea of building up, up, up that was going on in our country at the time, all of this excessive building, and not really dealing with what was in front of us. And we all know how that ended. That crashed and burned. It was a catastrophe. And that line came to me because it felt so indicative of what was going on in my life as well. And, eight years later, it’s really interesting that now, here we are again, not seeing what’s happening in our country, not wanting to put into perspective all of these ugly things that are staring us in the face.

I tried to keep myself busy
 I ran around in circles
 Think I made myself dizzy
 I slept it away, I sexed it away
 I read it away

The third verse notes Solange becoming introverted; she busies herself with menial tasks and basic, homely pleasures such as sleep, sex and escaping with a good read. Note how for the first time in the song, the context changes from “I tried to — it away”  to simply,  “I — it away.” This suggests that these methods may have actually succeeded in restoring a small slice of her happiness.

Solange’s focus cleverly shifts from appearance to appeasement in the song. Through grounding herself, she manages to truly revitalise her mind and inner self – rather than simply morphing her outward perception for the approval of others.

I ran my credit card bill up
 Thought a new dress would make it better
 I tried to work it away
 But that just made me even sadder

In this verse, Solange explains how she tried to drown her angst with consumerism and material things. But losing herself in her work simply worsened her mental condition—the reality is that since the 1970s, black women have received 10-14% less pay compared to their white counterparts in America.

I tried to let go my lover
 Thought if I was alone then maybe I could recover
 To write it away or cry it away (Don’t you cry, baby)

One facet of Solange’s pain is the loss of a lover, whether it is due to unrequited love or a break-up. She isolated herself, which is a symptom of heartbreak. It’s possible Solange is alluding to her divorce, since this song was written not too long after it occurred.

In dealing with her grief, she tried writing and also cried. However, she reached the conclusion that crying wouldn’t help her all that much, and turned to the catharsis writing can produce.

In an episode of the podcast “Song Exploder” Solange said that the “don’t you cry baby” three part vocal harmony represents the voices of her mother Tina Knowles, her aunt Bernell, and her aunt Janelle consoling and encouraging Solange to persevere. Growing up, her mother Tina emphasized the importance of both mourning, and rising. Solange said that Tina “always since we were kids, allowed us two days to mope and stay in bed and have our little pity parties. But on that third day, you get your ass up and you ride.”
https://soundcloud.com/hrishihirway/song-exploder-solange
Away

The repetition in the refrain represents Solange trying to push her negative emotions away, similar to a mantra. In a recent interview with Vogue about the video for “Cranes In The Sky,” Solange admitted that the song and visual is a plea for the black community to move away from relying on material things for internal happiness, as instead they should be working to cleanse themselves of anger or sadness.

I wanted to showcase how we’re always moving in these spaces, and distracting ourselves with all of these worldly things. Honestly I wanted the video to be like a meditation, and really center myself in God’s work.

With each repetition of the word “away,” her vocals become louder and supporting singers join in successively. This signifies her recruiting other black women to unburden themselves through reflection, focus, and caring for themselves. The chorus releases their pain and worries, letting them float away.

I tried to run it away
 Thought then my head’d be feeling clearer
 I traveled seventy states
 Thought moving ’round’d make me feel better

Solange explained this line in an episode of Radiotopia’s podcast Song Exploder beginning at 8:57 in the podcast:

I’ve lived in, I guess now Houston, Idaho, LA, New York, and here in New Orleans and there was a certain sense of me traveling seventy states in the physical sense and literal form to find home. To find peace. But when I talk about “ 70 states” its seventy states of mind, to finally achieve this feeling and not being able to really get there.

The week after this album dropped, Solange made a post on her Instagram thanking her husband Alan Ferguson for travelling the 70 states with her.

https://www.instagram.com/p/BLG2528hwGQ/?taken-by=saintrecords&hl=en

I tried to drink it away
 I tried to put one in the air
 I tried to dance it away
 I tried to change it with my hair

In 2008, Solange was trying to find ways to deal with the pain she was experiencing – not only as a recent divorcee,  but during her adjustment to life as a single parent. As an African-American mother, she is rightly anxious about the way her race has (and continues to be) treated in America.

 As Police shootings of unarmed black people and systematic racism in the justice system have caused social unrest for many African-Americans.

While trying to get over her pain or suffering, Solange tried many things to get her mind off her internal conflict and sadness.  In the first verse she becomes an extrovert, drowning her worries with loud music, weed, alcohol and dancing. All these actions are intended to numb and disguise her inner pain, so she seems perfectly content from the outside.

Well, it’s like cranes in the sky
 Sometimes, I don’t wanna feel those metal clouds
 Yeah, it’s like cranes in the sky
 Sometimes, I don’t wanna feel those metal clouds

The feelings of rejection Solange is experiencing are omnipresent and inescapable, looming over her life like metal cranes  at an ugly construction site. The work done by the cranes is  analogous to her emotional recovery.



Solange gave greater detail on her “Cranes in the Sky” analogy in her 2017 interview conducted by her superstar sister, Beyoncé for Interview magazine.

I remember looking up and seeing all of these cranes in the sky. They were so heavy and such an eyesore, and not what I identified with peace and refuge. I remember thinking of it as an analogy for my transition—this idea of building up, up, up that was going on in our country at the time, all of this excessive building, and not really dealing with what was in front of us. And we all know how that ended. That crashed and burned. It was a catastrophe. And that line came to me because it felt so indicative of what was going on in my life as well. And, eight years later, it’s really interesting that now, here we are again, not seeing what’s happening in our country, not wanting to put into perspective all of these ugly things that are staring us in the face.

description.plain:
An unlikely trio, “Almeda” marks the first time Solange, The-Dream and Playboi Carti have ever worked together.

The song heavily draws from the roots and traditions of Solange’s Southern black culture, influenced from growing up in Houston. She also shows her pride in her black faith by listing an array of traits that are exclusive to African-Americans.

The song is also an ode to the chopped and screwed genre, a remixing technique that also originated in the Houston hip-hop scene in the early 1990s.

The song’s title “Almeda” is also the name of an area located in Southwest Houston.

The song heavily draws from the roots and traditions of Solange’s Southern black culture, influenced from growing up in Houston. She also shows her pride in her black faith by listing an array of traits that are exclusive to African-Americans.

annotations:
Brown liquor, brown liquor
 Brown skin, brown face
 Brown leather, brown sugar
 Brown leaves, brown keys
 Brown creepers, brown face
 Black skin, black braids
 Black waves, black days
 Black baes, black things
 These are black-owned things

Solange discusses a problem of white society appropriating beauty standards to make it look that blacks are not “up to par” or “not pretty” a prime example of this is beauty magazines portraying black girls with straightened hair instead of their natural curly hair.
Black molasses, blackberry the masses

This may be a nod to Mista’s classic June 1996 track, “Blackberry Molasses,” a song about enduring hard times.

Solange’s use of the phrase, “Blackberry the masses,” may be a play on the idiom, “the blacker the berry, the sweeter the juice,” which highlights the positive nature of dark skin, and reinforces her message of black empowerment. Moreover, “Bury the masses,” encourages black people to embrace their heritage and take over.

Young nigga too cool
 Young nigga big bool

Carti affiliates with Bloods and also has friends who are Crips. Bloods are known to replace any word that starts with the letter ‘c,’ with ‘b.’ On his May 2018 track, “Shoota,” he says:

I got red shooters, I got blue (Yeah)

Black faith still can’t be washed away
 Not even in that Florida water
 Not even in that Florida water
 In that Florida water

At the May 2018 Met Gala, Solange carried a bottle of Florida Water, which E! commentators mistook to be her favorite drink—it’s actually a unisex cologne based on a mixture of essential oils.



Florida water is purported to have spiritual and healing effects, and it has been popular in Voodoo, Hoodoo, Wiccan, and Santeria circles. Voodoo in particular may be close to home for Solange considering that her mother, Tina Knowles, is Louisiana Creole. Solange believes, however, that no matter how effective the water, it can’t waver the hope and perseverance of black people facing adversity.

Solange may also be referencing 2005’s Hurricane Katrina, which started in Florida and made its way to Louisiana, causing $125 billion in damages, 1,833 fatalities, and 220,000 evacuations. Many African-Americans migrated to her home state of Texas. That same year, the Knowles family founded the Surviver Foundation, a charity that provides transitional housing for those displaced by the hurricane, and she was the headline performer at the ten-year anniversary Make It Right benefit concert held in New Orleans.
All black coupe (Hol’ up, yeah)

In December 2018, Iggy Azalea, Carti’s then-girlfriend, gifted the 22-year-old rapper a new black Lamborghini.

https://twitter.com/IggyWorldNews/status/1079558207293534208
I’ma die lit, bitch, I promise (Hol’ up)

Carti plugs his May 2018 debut studio album, Die Lit. The Atlanta rapper had a very similar lyric on his unreleased track, “Bouldercrest”:

I'ma die next to the mob (Die)
I'ma die lit cause I got to (Brrt)

description.plain:
“Binz' features contributions from R&B legend The-Dream as well from as the renowned experimental pop artist Panda Bear of Animal Collective. The song "Didn’t Want to Have to Do It” by Rotary Connection is sampled at the tail-end of the track.
https://youtu.be/XwDHitCW8Ic?t=9

Topically, Solange sings about getting money and living lavishly while breaking the stereotype of black people being poor.

Additionally, in a partnership with Sonos, “Binz” was featured in a viral commercial promoting the Sonos home sound system.

annotations: I just wanna wake up on CP time

While CP time is seen as a negative stereotype (as mentioned in the previous annotation), Solange wants to be able to live a life that is so easygoing and flexible that it almost affirms the stereotype.

What, you have a comment?
 No, I didn’t say anything, I didn’t say nothin’

This is a sample from Alexyss K. Tylor’s Vagina Power: “Halloween Show”. It involves an interaction between the host and her mother regarding a comment she made about saluting the vagina.
https://youtu.be/nWTahnFH4F8?t=130
Tylor is also sampled in “We Deal with the Freak'n (Intermission). She is generally known for discussing the spirituality of sex and the sacred nature of the vagina.
Dollars never show up on CP time

“CP time” or “colored people’s time” refers to a negative stereotype that African-Americans are always tardy to events.

The term is said to have appeared as early as 1912 in a Chicago newspaper. In the 1960s, anthropologist Jules Henry spent more than a year interviewing “mostly poor African-American families living in a St. Louis housing development”. The New York Times wrote about his findings, which found “CP time” to be:

a scheduled event may occur at any moment over a wide spread of hours–or perhaps not at all.“ [His] interviewees were quick to point out how sharply this contrasted with the highly organized, precisely scheduled world of white people.

Solange seeks to convey that she consistently accumulates wealth and does not have to worry about problems such as a late check. Furthermore, she may be saying that her success is not anchored down by derogatory stereotypes of African-Americans.

description.plain:
Solange Knowles returns to music after a four-year hiatus with the release of the single and video for “Losing You,” which explores the end of a relationship.

The singer/songwriter/model’s slow sonic evolution has been a captivating one to watch since she released her 2003 debut of inoffensive pop-R&B.

Produced by Blood Orange’s Devonté Hynes, “Losing You,” is a sticky mid-tempo dance-R&B cut that pushes her further away from unfair comparisons.

song.embed_content: Read “Losing You” by Solange on Genius
song.title: Losing You

body.plain:
Solange Knowles returns to music after a four-year hiatus with the release of the single and video for “Losing You,” which explores the end of a relationship.

The singer/songwriter/model’s slow sonic evolution has been a captivating one to watch since she released her 2003 debut of inoffensive pop-R&B.

Produced by Blood Orange’s Devonté Hynes, “Losing You,” is a sticky mid-tempo dance-R&B cut that pushes her further away from unfair comparisons.

songs.full_title: Losing You by Will Young
songs.title: Losing You

annotations:
Baby, you know I
 Can’t lose you from my life
The edited in interludes of the chorus echo the emotion of the incoming break-up, and how Solange has attempted to continue her romance, despite her lover not wanting the same.

Baby, you know I tried
 Can’t lose you from my life
The edited in interludes of the chorus echo the emotion of the incoming break-up, and how Solange has attempted to continue her romance, despite her lover not wanting the same.

Baby, you know I tried
 How could you waste my time?
The edited in interludes of the chorus echo the emotion of the incoming break-up, and how Solange has attempted to continue her romance, despite her lover not wanting the same.

I’m not the one that you should be making your enemy
 I’m not the one that you should be making your enemy

This repeated line, in the context of the second verse, sounds equally threatening as apologetic. She could be saying that he shouldn’t have her as an enemy, because she’s treating him fairly and she doesn’t want the relationship to end.

On the other side, she could mean it in a threatening tone. In an interview, Solange explained that while at the time of writing True, she was in a happy relationship with her now husband Alex Ferguson, while co-writer Dev Hynes aka Blood Orange was going through a tough time in his relationship. It seems that the general tone of the song comes from his mind. Compare for example his 2012' single “Dinner,” also about a break-up, has lines like

Hoping that you’re still unhappy
I’ll do everything I can
To make sure that you are never happy

So it rather seems like Hynes is dealing with his relationship here, threatening his partner not to mess with him, because he’ll do everything. Solange’s voice however, appeases this reading a little, rather mourning that she doesn’t want to make an enemy and rather break up for good.

description.plain:
Originally written about four years ago, “Rise” was the first song written for Solange’s third full-length album A Seat At The Table, and now serves as the record’s opening track.

The lyrics advocate staying true to oneself, in times of both success and failure. Solange has stated on Twitter that the album is meant to “provoke healing & journey of self empowerment.”

song.embed_content: Read “Rise” by Solange on Genius
song.title: Rise

album.full_title: A Seat at the Table by Solange
album.name: A Seat at the Table

body.plain:
Originally written about four years ago, “Rise” was the first song written for Solange’s third full-length album A Seat At The Table, and now serves as the record’s opening track.

The lyrics advocate staying true to oneself, in times of both success and failure. Solange has stated on Twitter that the album is meant to “provoke healing & journey of self empowerment.”

annotations:
Fall in your ways, so you can crumble
 Fall in your ways, so you can sleep at night
 Fall in your ways, so you can wake up and rise

Solange is saying be who you are, flipping the normal connotation that accompanies the similar phrase “stuck in your ways.” Being in your ways here is turned on its head and is a nod to the overall theme of the album as a “journey of self-empowerment.”

The repetition here works as a tool to emphasize that each day you will wake up as the same person; each day you’ll have to work through things and each day you’ll go to sleep to do it all over again.  The only thing that can be changed is the way you view it, will you “fall” because of it  or will you “walk” with it?

Walk in your ways, so you won’t crumble
 (so you won’t crumble)
 Walk in your ways, so you can sleep at night
 Walk in your ways, so you will wake up and rise

There are ups (walk) and there are downs (fall) when you live your truth.

If ‘“fall” in your ways’ is about accepting yourself and your failures so that you can move on, ‘“walk” in your ways’ embodies that movement forward, the eventual positive growth, that makes all that stress and self-care worthwhile.

description.plain: It can be guessed that this song is about the TX-8 Beltway or ‘Beltway 8’; a loop that runs around the circumference of the city of Houston, the place where Solange was born. From the beat it sounds like she’s passing by concrete barriers with the window down. The song that follows is “Exit Scott” which is an exit on Beltway 8 in the southern part of Houston.
